title: Common Mistakes When Teaching Soroban (And How to Avoid Them)
description: Even well-meaning parents and tutors make these errors. Here's what to watch out for.
imageAlt: Teacher correcting soroban technique with student

content.intro: I've trained over 100 parents and tutors to teach soroban. These are the mistakes I see most often – and they're all fixable.

sections.text: "They got it, let's move on." Famous last words. Kids might get simple addition once, but soroban requires automaticity. You need to master each step before building on it.
Stay at each level until accuracy is 95%+ AND speed is consistent. Mastery isn't "got it once" – it's "can't get it wrong."
Which finger moves which bead matters. Sloppy technique at the start leads to ceiling later. Correct form now, even if it slows them down.

items: Thumb for pushing unit beads UP
Index finger for pushing unit beads DOWN
Index finger for both directions on heaven bead
One hand only, other hand holds the soroban steady

sections.text: Teaching addition, subtraction, and complement rules in one session? Overwhelm. Teach one thing. Practice it for days. Then add the next thing.
Long explanations of WHY the 5-complement works. Kids don't need the theory. They need to DO it. Explanation can come later, after muscle memory forms.
30 minutes Tuesday, nothing until Saturday, then an hour. This doesn't build skill. 5-10 minutes daily, every day, no exceptions.
Mistake #6: Jumping to Mental Math Too Soon
"Okay, now do it in your head!" But the bead movements aren't automatic yet. Mental math (anzan) requires the physical motions to be unconscious first.

rows: Eyes closed, fingers still move correctly
Need to look at beads constantly

sections.text: "Emma can already do 3-digit! Why can't you?" Comparison kills motivation. Every child learns at their own pace. Compare only to their past self.
Small wins matter. Completed level 5? Celebrate! Fastest time yet? Notice it! Positive reinforcement builds association between soroban and good feelings.

faq.question: How do I know if I'm going too fast?
faq.answer: If accuracy drops below 90% on material they "already learned," you moved too fast. Go back and reinforce.

faq.question: What if I'm not confident teaching soroban myself?
faq.answer: Use an app or program designed for self-learning. The best ones guide progression and ensure proper technique.

faq.question: Is it bad to learn alongside my child?
faq.answer: No! It's great! Kids love seeing parents learn and make mistakes too. Models growth mindset.

cta.text: SoroKid is designed to avoid all these mistakes with structured, self-paced learning.
